QuestionText: Which of these is an example of Human Resources confidential information?
Which of these is considered commercially sensitive information?
Which of these is considered access information?
Why must salary information be kept confidential?
OptionA: To prevent competitors from offering higher wages
OptionB: To allow employees to compare salaries

QuestionText: Why must staff details be kept confidential?
OptionA: To protect privacy and prevent competitors from contacting them

QuestionText: Why must intellectual property be kept confidential?
OptionA: To prevent competitors from copying designs
OptionB: To allow free sharing of ideas

QuestionText: What is a potential impact of failing to maintain confidentiality?
Which of these is a financial consequence of failing to maintain confidentiality?
Which of these is a legal consequence of failing to maintain confidentiality?
Name something
What is a common business impact of leaking sensitive data?
Loss of sensitive data often leads to:
OptionA: Customer churn and loss of trust

QuestionText: Unauthorised access to digital systems can allow attackers to:
A likely result of unauthorised access is:
Data corruption primarily impacts:
Corrupted records in a finance system can cause:
Service disruption (e.g., DDoS) most directly causes:
Extended downtime may lead to:
Unauthorised access to restricted physical areas can result in:
Physical breaches of server rooms can cause:
OptionB: Direct hardware theft or data destruction

QuestionText: A reputational impact of a breach is typically:
OptionB: Negative media coverage and brand damage

QuestionText: Regulatory non?compliance after a data leak may trigger:
Operational impact of ransomware includes:
A data integrity incident typically requires:
Credential compromise often results in:
Supply?chain disruption due to a provider outage can:
OptionB: Cascade into your own service disruption

QuestionText: Which network type typically covers the smallest geographical area?
Description: PAN covers the smallest area (personal/near?body range).

QuestionText: A LAN usually covers which type of area?
Description: A LAN typically spans a building or campus.

QuestionText: Which network type spans across countries or continents?
Description: WAN interconnects over large, cross?country distances.

QuestionText: Bluetooth is most commonly used in which type of network?
Description: Bluetooth is a short?range PAN technology.

QuestionText: Fibre optic cable is an example of which type of connection media?
Description: Fibre is a guided/wired medium using light in optical fibre.

QuestionText: Wi?Fi is an example of what type of network media?
Description: Wi?Fi is a wireless radio medium.

QuestionText: A MAN typically connects multiple:
Description: MAN links multiple buildings across a city.

QuestionText: Which connection media is most susceptible to electromagnetic interference?
Description: Copper cabling is most affected by EMI compared to fibre.

QuestionText: Which model uses a central server to manage resources?
Description: Client?server centralises resource control on a server.

QuestionText: Which model is easiest and cheapest to set up for a small number of users?
Description: Peer?to?peer is simplest and cheapest for small groups.

QuestionText: A thin client mainly relies on:
Description: Thin clients depend on a central server for processing.

QuestionText: Which is a drawback of a peer?to?peer network?
Description: P2P is harder to manage and secure without central control.

QuestionText: Which model provides the strongest centralised security?
Description: Client?server enables strong centralised policies and auth.

QuestionText: Which device forwards data packets between different networks?
Description: Routers forward packets between different IP networks.

QuestionText: A switch operates mainly at which OSI layer?
Description: Switches operate at OSI Layer 2 (Data Link).

QuestionText: Which device typically stores user accounts, files, and authentication services?
Description: Servers host user accounts, files, and authentication.

QuestionText: The Internet backbone is best described as:
OptionB: The central high?speed infrastructure of the internet
Description: It�s the high?speed core infrastructure of the internet.

QuestionText: Which OSI layer is responsible for physically transmitting bits across media?
Description: The Physical layer transmits raw bits over the medium.

QuestionText: Which OSI layer assigns IP addresses and handles routing?
Description: The Network layer handles IP addressing and routing.

QuestionText: Encryption and decryption occur at which layer?
Description: Presentation layer handles data representation and encryption.

QuestionText: TCP and UDP operate at which OSI layer?
Description: TCP and UDP are Transport?layer protocols.

QuestionText: The session layer is responsible for:
Description: The Session layer establishes and manages sessions.

QuestionText: HTTP and FTP work at which OSI layer?
Description: HTTP and FTP are Application?layer protocols.

QuestionText: In the TCP/IP model, IP operates at which layer?
Description: IP resides in the Internet layer of TCP/IP.

QuestionText: Which layer of the TCP/IP model handles end?to?end communication?
Description: The Transport layer provides end?to?end delivery.

QuestionText: The TCP/IP Application layer corresponds to which three OSI layers?
Description: TCP/IP Application maps to OSI layers 5�7.

QuestionText: Which protocol belongs to the TCP/IP Transport layer?
Description: TCP is a Transport?layer protocol.

QuestionText: Which part of a data packet contains the data being transmitted?
Description: The payload is the actual user data in the packet.

QuestionText: CRC is used for:
Description: CRC provides error detection by checking frame integrity.

QuestionText: Packet switching can cause packet loss due to:
Description: Congestion leads to queue drops and packet loss.

QuestionText: The trailer of a packet typically contains:
Description: Frame trailers carry error?checking information (e.g., FCS).

QuestionText: Which protocol transfers web pages over the internet?
Description: HTTP is the protocol for transferring web pages.

QuestionText: HTTPS is more secure than HTTP because it uses:
Description: HTTPS adds TLS encryption over HTTP.

QuestionText: Which protocol is used to send email from a client to a mail server?
Description: SMTP is used to send mail from clients to servers.

QuestionText: Which protocol downloads email from a mail server and removes it?
Description: POP retrieves and typically deletes email from the server.

QuestionText: Which routing protocol is a distance?vector protocol?
Description: RIP is a distance?vector routing protocol.

QuestionText: Which routing protocol uses link?state routing?
Description: OSPF is a link?state routing protocol.

QuestionText: Which protocol is used to assign IP addresses automatically?
Description: DHCP dynamically assigns IP addresses to hosts.

QuestionText: Which protocol resolves domain names to IP addresses?
Description: DNS resolves domain names to IP addresses.

QuestionText: SFTP is more secure than FTP because it:
Description: Encrypts data

QuestionText: Which OSI layer is responsible for end-user network services such as email and web browsing?
Description: Application

QuestionText: Which OSI layer handles data encryption, compression, and translation?
Description: Presentation

QuestionText: Which OSI layer establishes, manages, and terminates communication sessions?
Description: Session

QuestionText: TCP and UDP operate at which OSI layer?
Description: Transport

QuestionText: Which OSI layer handles logical addressing and routing?
Description: Network

QuestionText: MAC addressing operates at which OSI layer?
Description: Data Link

QuestionText: Which OSI layer transmits raw bits over physical media?
Description: Physical

QuestionText: At which OSI layer do switches primarily operate?
Description: Data Link

QuestionText: At which OSI layer do routers operate?
Description: Network

QuestionText: Which OSI layer is responsible for reliable or unreliable delivery of data segments?
Description: Transport

QuestionText: Which TCP/IP layer combines OSI layers 5, 6, and 7?
Description: Application

QuestionText: The TCP/IP Internet layer corresponds to which OSI layer?
Description: Network

QuestionText: Which TCP/IP layer is responsible for end-to-end communication and flow control?
Description: Transport

QuestionText: The Network Access layer of TCP/IP corresponds to which OSI layers?
Description: Data Link + Physical

QuestionText: Which protocol operates at the TCP/IP Internet layer?
Description: IP

QuestionText: Which protocol operates at the TCP/IP Transport layer?
Description: TCP

QuestionText: HTTP, FTP, and DNS operate at which TCP/IP layer?
Description: Application

QuestionText: Which OSI layer packages data into frames?
Description: Data Link

QuestionText: Which OSI layer converts frames into bits for transmission?
Description: Physical

QuestionText: Which TCP/IP layer handles physical addressing and defining how data is transmitted over media?
Description: Network Access

QuestionText: What is the primary purpose of a data packet?
OptionA: To transmit data across a network
Description: To transmit data across a network

QuestionText: Which part of a data packet contains the actual data being carried?
Description: Payload

QuestionText: What does the header of a data packet usually contain?
Description: Source and destination addresses

QuestionText: What is the function of the trailer in a data packet?
Description: Error detection

QuestionText: Which component is used in packets to detect errors?
Description: CRC

QuestionText: CRC stands for:
Description: Cyclic Redundancy Check

QuestionText: Packet switching breaks data into:
Description: Packets

QuestionText: Which process allows packets to take different paths across a network?
Description: Packet switching

QuestionText: A common cause of packet loss is:
Description: Network congestion

QuestionText: Which of the following is NOT a cause of packet loss?
Description: Correct packet sequencing

QuestionText: Packet switching is mainly used in:
Description: Modern digital networks

QuestionText: Which term describes when packets arrive out of order?
Description: Packet reordering

QuestionText: Which part of a packet ensures data has not been corrupted?
Description: CRC value
